Sums, series, and products in Diophantine approximation

Jordan Bell
jordan.bell@gmail.com
Department of Mathematics, University of Toronto
Toronto, Ontario, Canada
(March 3, 2023)
Abstract

There is not much that can be said for all x and for all n about the sum

‚àëk=1n1|sin‚Å°k‚Å¢œÄ‚Å¢x|.

However, for this and similar sums, series, and products, we can establish results for almost all x using the tools of continued fractions. We present in detail the appearance of these sums in the singular series for the circle method. One particular interest of the paper is the detailed proof of a striking result of Hardy and Littlewood, whose compact proof, which delicately uses analytic continuation, has not been written freshly anywhere since its original publication. This story includes various parts of late 19th century and early 20th century mathematics.

1 Introduction

In this paper we survey a class of estimates for sums, series, and products that involve Diophantine approximation. We both sort out a timeline of the literature on these questions and give careful proofs of many lesser known results. Rather than being an open-pit mine for the history of Diophantine approximation, this paper follows one vein as deep as it goes.

For x‚àà‚Ñù, we write ‚à•x‚à•=minn‚àà‚Ñ§‚Å°|x-n|, the distance from x to a nearest integer. In this paper we give a comprehensive presentation of estimates for sums whose jth term involves ‚à•j‚Å¢x‚à• and determine the abscissa of convergence and radius of convergence respectively of Dirichlet series and power series whose jth term involves ‚à•j‚Å¢x‚à•. We also give a detailed proof of a result of Hardy and Littlewood that

limn‚Üí‚àû‚Å°(‚àèk=1n|sin‚Å°k‚Å¢œÄ‚Å¢x|)1/n=12

for almost all x.

We either prove or state in detail and give references for all the material on continued fractions and measure theory that we use in this paper. Many of the results we prove in this paper do not have detailed proofs written in any books, and the proofs we give for results that do have proofs in books are often written significantly more meticulously here than anywhere else; in some cases the proofs in the literature are so sketchy that the proof we give is written from scratch, for example Lemma 9. Our presentation of Hardy and Littlewood‚Äôs estimate for ‚àèk=1n|sin‚Å°œÄ‚Å¢k‚Å¢x| makes clear exactly what results in Diophantine approximation one needs for the proof.

In the next section we introduce the Bernoulli polynomials, the Euler-Maclaurin summation formula, and Euler‚Äôs constant, which we shall use in a few places. Because the calculations are similar to what we do in the rest of this paper and because we want to be comfortable using Bernoulli polynomials, we work things out from scratch rather than merely stating results as known. In the section after that we summarize various problems that involve sums of the type we are talking about in this paper.

3 Background

For x‚àà‚Ñù, let [x] be the greatest integer ‚â§x and let R‚Å¢(x)=x-[x]. It will be handy to review some properties of x‚Ü¶[x]. For n‚àà‚Ñ§ it is immediate that [x+n]=[x]. For x,y‚àà‚Ñù we have 0‚â§x-[x]+y-[y]<2, which means 0=[0]‚â§[x-[y]+y-[y]]<[2]=2, and using [x+n]=[x] this is 0‚â§[x+y]-[x]-[y]<2, therefore

[x]+[y]‚â§[x+y]‚â§[x]+[y]+1.

For m,n‚àà‚Ñ§, n>1, and x‚àà‚Ñù,

[x+mn]=[[x]+mn].

For n a positive integer and for real x,

[x]=[x+0n]‚â§[x+1n]‚â§‚ãØ‚Å¢[x+n-1n]‚â§[x+nn]=[x]+1.

There is a unique ŒΩ, 1‚â§ŒΩ‚â§n, such that [x+ŒΩ-1n]=[x] and [x+ŒΩn]=[x]+1, and therefore [R‚Å¢(x)+ŒΩ-1n]=0 and [R‚Å¢(x)+ŒΩn]=1, consequently R‚Å¢(x)+ŒΩ-1n<1 and R‚Å¢(x)+ŒΩn‚â•1, which means 1-ŒΩn‚â§R‚Å¢(x)<1-ŒΩ-1n, from which finally we get n‚â§[n‚Å¢x]-n‚Å¢[x]+ŒΩ<n+1 and so n=[n‚Å¢x]-n‚Å¢[x]+ŒΩ. But

‚àëk=0n-1[x+kn]=‚àëk=0ŒΩ-1[x]+‚àëk=ŒΩn-1([x]+1)=ŒΩ‚Å¢[x]+(n-ŒΩ)‚Å¢([x]+1)=n‚Å¢[x]+n-ŒΩ,

and using ŒΩ=n-[n‚Å¢x]+n‚Å¢[x],

‚àëk=0n-1[x+kn]=n‚Å¢[x]+n-(n-[n‚Å¢x]+n‚Å¢[x])=[n‚Å¢x].

This identity is proved by Hermite [65, pp.¬†310‚Äì315, ¬ßV].

The Legendre symbol is defined in the following way. Let p be an odd prime, and let a be an integer that is not a multiple of p. If there is an integer b such that a‚â°b2(modp) then (ap)=1, and otherwise (ap)=-1. In other words, for an integer a that is relatively prime to p, if a is a square mod p then (ap)=1, and if a is not a square mod p then (ap)=-1. For example, one checks that there is no integer b such that b2‚â°6(mod7), and hence (67)=-1, while 32‚â°2(mod7), and so (27)=1.

If p and q are distinct odd primes, define integers uk, 1‚â§k‚â§p-12, by

k‚Å¢q=p‚Å¢[k‚Å¢qp]+uk;

namely, uk is the remainder of k‚Å¢q when divided by p. We have 1‚â§uk‚â§p-1. Let Œº‚Å¢(q,p) be the number of k such that uk>p-12. It can be shown that [59, p.¬†74, Theorem 92]

(qp)=(-1)Œº‚Å¢(q,p);

this fact is called Gauss‚Äôs lemma. For example, for p=13 and q=3 we work out that

u1=3,u2=6,u3=9,u4=12,u5=2,u6=5,

and hence Œº‚Å¢(3,13)=2, so (-1)Œº‚Å¢(3,13)=1; on the other hand, 42‚â°3(mod13), hence (313)=1. With

S‚Å¢(q,p)=‚àëj=1p-12[j‚Å¢qp],

it is known that [59, pp.¬†77-78, ¬ß6.13]

S‚Å¢(q,p)‚â°Œº‚Å¢(q,p)(mod2).

And it can be shown that [59, p.¬†76, Theorem 100]

S‚Å¢(q,p)+S‚Å¢(p,q)=p-12‚ãÖq-12. (4)

Thus

(pq)‚Å¢(qp) = (-1)Œº‚Å¢(p,q)+Œº‚Å¢(q,p)
= (-1)S‚Å¢(p,q)+S‚Å¢(q,p)
= (-1)p-12‚ãÖq-12.

This is Gauss‚Äôs third proof of the law of quadratic reciprocity in the numbering [7, p.¬†50, ¬ß20]. This proof was published in Gauss‚Äôs 1808 ‚ÄúTheorematis arithmetici demonstratio nova‚Äù, which is translated in [140, pp.¬†112‚Äì118]. Dirichlet [38, pp.¬†65‚Äì72, ¬ß¬ß42‚Äì44] gives a presentation of the proof. Eisenstein‚Äôs streamlined version of Gauss‚Äôs third proof is presented with historical remarks in [93]. Lemmermeyer [95] gives a comprehensive history of the law of quadratic reciprocity, and in particular writes about Gauss‚Äôs third proof [95, pp.¬†9‚Äì10]. The formula (4) resembles the reciprocity formula for Dedekind sums [123, p.¬†4, Theorem¬†1].

Gauss obtains (4) from the following [140, p.¬†116, ¬ß5]: if x is irrational and n is a positive integer, then

‚àëk=1n[k‚Å¢x]+‚àëk=1[n‚Å¢x][kx]=n‚Å¢[n‚Å¢x], (5)

which he proves as follows. If [jx]<k‚â§[j+1x], then [k‚Å¢x]=j. Therefore

‚àëk=1n[k‚Å¢x] = ‚àëj=1[n‚Å¢x]j‚Å¢([j+1x]-[jx])
= n‚Å¢[n‚Å¢x]-‚àëj=1[n‚Å¢x][jx].

Bachmann [6, pp.¬†654‚Äì658, ¬ß4] surveys later work on sums similar to (5); see also Dickson [35, Chapter X]. If m and n are relatively prime, then

{R‚Å¢(mn),R‚Å¢(2‚Å¢mn),‚Ä¶,R‚Å¢((n-1)‚Å¢mn)}={1n,2n,‚Ä¶,n-1n},

and so

‚àëk=1n-1R‚Å¢(k‚Å¢mn)=‚àëk=1n-1kn=1n‚ãÖ(n-1)‚Å¢n2=n-12.

Hence

‚àëk=1n-1[k‚Å¢mn]=‚àëk=1n-1k‚Å¢mn-‚àëk=1n-1R‚Å¢(k‚Å¢mn)=(m-1)‚Å¢(n-1)2. (6)

There is also a simple lattice point counting argument [118, p.¬†113, No.¬†18] that gives (6).

In 1849, Dirichlet [37] shows that

‚àëk=1nd‚Å¢(k)=‚àëk=1n[nk],

where d‚Å¢(n) denotes the number of positive divisors of an integer n. (This equality is Dirichlet‚Äôs ‚Äúhyperbola method‚Äù.) He then proves that

‚àëk=1n[nk]=n‚Å¢log‚Å°n+(2‚Å¢Œ≥-1)‚Å¢n+O‚Å¢(n).

Hardy and Wright [59, pp.¬†264‚Äì265, Theorem 320] give a proof of this. Finding the best possible error term in the estimate for ‚àëk=1nd‚Å¢(k) is ‚ÄúDirichlet‚Äôs divisor problem‚Äù. Dirichlet cites the end of Section V Gauss‚Äôs Disquisitiones Arithmeticae as precedent for determining average magnitudes of arithmetic functions. (In Section V, Articles 302‚Äì304, of the Disquisitiones Arithmeticae, Gauss writes about averages of class numbers of binary quadratic forms, cf. [36, Chapter VI].)

Define (x) to be 0 if x‚àà‚Ñ§+12; if x‚àâ‚Ñ§+12 then there is an integer mx for which |x-mx|<|x-n| for all integers n‚â†mx, and we define (x) to be x-mx. Riemann [125, p.¬†105, ¬ß6] defines

f‚Å¢(x)=‚àën=1‚àû(n‚Å¢x)n2;

thus

f‚Å¢(x-)-f‚Å¢(x+)=œÄ28‚Å¢m2,

and hence that f is discontinuous at such points, and says that at all other points f is continuous; see Laugwitz [94, ¬ß2.1.1, pp. 183-184], Neuenschwander [108], and Pringsheim [119, p.¬†37] about Riemann‚Äôs work on pathological functions. The role of pathological functions in the development of set theory is explained by Dauben [32, Chapter 1, p. 19] and Ferreir√≥s [49, Chapter V, ¬ß1, p. 152].

For any interval [a,b] and any œÉ>0, it is apparent from the above that there are only finitely many x‚àà[a,b] for which f‚Å¢(x-)-f‚Å¢(x+)>œÉ, and Riemann deduces from this that f is Riemann integrable on [a,b]; cf. Hawkins [63, p.¬†18] on the history of Riemann integration. Later in the same paper [125, p.¬†129, ¬ß13], Riemann states that the function

x‚Ü¶‚àën=1‚àû(n‚Å¢x)n,

is not Riemann integrable in any interval.

In 1897, Ces√†ro [28] asks the following question (using the pseudonym, and anagram, ‚ÄúRosace‚Äù [112, p.¬†331]). Let œµ‚Å¢(x)=x-[x]-12. Is the series

‚àën=1‚àûœµ‚Å¢(n‚Å¢x)n (7)

convergent for all non-integer x? This is plausible because the expected value of œµ‚Å¢(x) is 0. Landau [89] answers this question in 1901. Landau proves that if there is some g such that

‚àëk=1n[k‚Å¢x]=n‚Å¢(n+1)‚Å¢x2-n2+O‚Å¢(g‚Å¢(n))

where g is a nonnegative function such g‚Å¢(n)=o‚Å¢(n) and such that ‚àën=1‚àûg‚Å¢(n)n‚Å¢(n+1) converges, then (7) converges. And he proves that if x is rational then (7) diverges. We return to this series in ¬ß9.

Also in 1898, Franel [52] asks whether for irrational x and for œµ>0 we have

‚àëk=1n[k‚Å¢x]=n‚Å¢(n+1)‚Å¢x2-n2+O‚Å¢(nœµ).

Then in 1899, Franel [53] asks if we can do better than this: is the error term in fact O‚Å¢(1)? Ces√†ro and Franel each contributed many problems to L‚ÄôInterm√©diaire des math√©maticiens, the periodical in which they posed their questions. Information about Franel is given in [82].

Lerch [96] answers Franel‚Äôs questions in 1904. If x is irrational and pq is a convergent of x (which we will define in ¬ß4), then using Theorem 2 (from ¬ß4) we can show that if 1‚â§k‚â§q then [k‚Å¢x]=[k‚Å¢pq]. Lerch uses this and (6) to show that if x is irrational and pq is a convergent of x then

‚àëk=1q[k‚Å¢x]=q‚Å¢(q+1)‚Å¢x2-q2+R,0<R<12.

Lerch states that if the continued fraction expansion of x has bounded partial quotients (defined in ¬ß4) then, for any positive integer n,

‚àëk=1n[k‚Å¢x]=n‚Å¢(n+1)‚Å¢x2-n2+O‚Å¢(log‚Å°n).

Lerch only gives a brief indication of the proof of this. This result is proved by Hardy and Littlewood in 1922 [57, p.¬†24, Theorem B3], and also in 1922 by Ostrowski [110, p.¬†81]. On the other hand, Lerch also constructs examples of x such that, for some positive integer c,

|‚àëk=1n[k‚Å¢x]-n‚Å¢(n+1)‚Å¢x2+n2|‚â´n1-1c.

Nevertheless, in 1909 Sierpinski [135] proves that if x is irrational then

‚àëk=1n[k‚Å¢x]=n‚Å¢(n+1)‚Å¢x2-n2+o‚Å¢(n).

A bibliography of Lerch‚Äôs works is given in [139]. Lerch had written earlier papers on Gauss sums, Fourier series, theta functions, and the class number; many of his papers are in Czech, but some of them are in French, several of which were published in the Paris Comptes rendus. Several of Lerch‚Äôs papers are discussed in Cresse‚Äôs survey of the class number of binary quadratic forms [36, Chapter VI].

In 1899, a writer using the pseudonym ‚ÄúQuemquaeris‚Äù [121] (‚Äúquem quaeris‚Äù = ‚Äúwhom you seek‚Äù) asks if we can characterize œï‚Å¢(n) such that for all irrational Œ∏ the series

converges. In particular, the writer asks if œï‚Å¢(n)=1n! satisfies this. In the same year, de la Vall√©e-Poussin [34] answers this question. (There are also responses following de la Vall√©e-Poussin‚Äôs by Borel and Fabry.) For a given function œï‚Å¢(n), de la Vall√©e-Poussin shows that if we have an>1œï‚Å¢(qn-1) for all n, for an the nth partial quotient of Œ∏ and qn the denominator of the nth convergent of Œ∏, then the series

will diverge. Hardy and Littlewood prove numerous results on similar series, e.g. for œï‚Å¢(n)=n-r for real r>1 and for certain classes of Œ∏, in their papers on Diophantine approximation [61]. In 1931, Walfisz [152, p.¬†570, Hilfssatz 4] shows, following work of Behnke [13, p.¬†289, ¬ß16], that for almost all irrational x‚àà[0,1], if œµ>0 then

‚àëk=1n1‚à•k‚Å¢Œ∏‚à•=O‚Å¢(n‚Å¢(log‚Å°n)2+œµ),

where ‚à•x‚à•=min‚Å°(R‚Å¢(x),1-R‚Å¢(x)). Walfisz‚Äôs paper includes many results on related sums.

In 1916, Watson [153] finds the following asymptotic series for Sn=‚àëm=1n-1csc‚Å°(m‚Å¢œÄn):

œÄ‚Å¢Sn‚àº2‚Å¢n‚Å¢log‚Å°(2‚Å¢n)+2‚Å¢n‚Å¢(Œ≥-log‚Å°œÄ)+‚àëj=1‚àû(-1)j‚Å¢B2‚Å¢j2‚Å¢(22‚Å¢j-2)‚Å¢œÄ2‚Å¢jj‚Å¢(2‚Å¢j)!‚Å¢n2‚Å¢j-1,

For example, computing S1000 directly we get S1000=4477.593932‚Å¢‚Ä¶, and computing the right-hand side of the above formula without the error term we obtain 4477.594019‚Å¢‚Ä¶ A cleaner derivation of the asymptotic series using the Euler-Maclaurin summation formula is given later by Williams [155].

Early surveys of Diophantine approximation are given by Bohr and Cram√©r [20, pp.¬†833‚Äì836, ¬ß39] and Koksma [81, pp.¬†102‚Äì110]. Hlawka and Binder [66] present the history of the initial years of the theory of uniform distribution. Narkiewicz [106, pp.¬†82‚Äì95, ¬ß2.5 and pp.¬†175‚Äì183 ¬ß3.5] gives additional historical references on Diophantine approximation. The papers of Hardy and Littlewood on Diophantine approximation are reprinted in [61]. Perron [113] and Brezinski [23] give historical references on continued fractions, and there is reliable material on the use of continued fractions by 17th century mathematicians in Whiteside [154]. Fowler [51] presents a prehistory of continued fractions in Greek mathematics.

A complex number Œ± is called an algebraic number of degree d, d‚â•0, if there is some polynomial f‚àà‚Ñ§‚Å¢[x] with degree d such that f‚Å¢(Œ±)=0 and if g‚àà‚Ñ§‚Å¢[x] has degree <d and g‚Å¢(Œ±)=0 then g=0. An algebraic number number of degree 2 is called a quadratic irrational. Let Œ±‚ààŒ©. It was proved by Euler [59, p.¬†144, Theorem 176] that if there is some p>0 and some L such that al+p‚Å¢(Œ±)=al‚Å¢(Œ±) for all l‚â•L then Œ± is a quadratic irrational The converse of this was proved by Lagrange [59, p.¬†144, Theorem 177], namely that a quadratic irrational has eventually periodic partial quotients. For example, Œ±=11-3‚ààŒ© is a quadratic irrational, being a root of x2+6‚Å¢x-2, and one works out that a1‚Å¢(Œ±)=3,a2‚Å¢(Œ±)=6, and that al+2‚Å¢(Œ±)=al‚Å¢(Œ±) for l‚â•1. In particular, if Œ±‚ààŒ© is a quadratic irrational, then Œ± has bounded partial quotients.

Liouville [59, p.¬†161, Theorem 191] proved that if x‚ààŒ© is an algebraic number of degree d‚â•2, then x‚ààùíü‚Å¢(d). The Thue-Siegel-Roth theorem [48, p.¬†55, Theorem 1.23] states that if x‚ààŒ© is an algebraic number, then for any Œ¥>0 there is some qŒ¥‚àà‚Ñ§‚â•1 such that for all q‚â•qŒ¥,

‚à•q‚Å¢x‚à•‚â•q-1-Œ¥.

See Schmidt [131, p.¬†195, Theorem 2B].

6 Sums of reciprocals

We are interested in getting bounds on the sum ‚àëj=1m1‚à•j‚Å¢x‚à•. This is an appealing question because the terms 1‚à•j‚Å¢x‚à• are unbounded.

Rather than merely stating that ‚àëk=1‚àû1k=‚àû, we give more information by giving the estimate

‚àëk=1n1k=log‚Å°n+Œ≥+O‚Å¢(n-1),

where Œ≥ is Euler‚Äôs constant. Likewise, rather than merely stating that there are infinitely many primes, we state more information with [90, p.¬†102, ¬ß28]

Because |sin‚Å°(œÄ‚Å¢x)|=sin‚Å°(œÄ‚Å¢‚à•x‚à•)‚â§œÄ‚Å¢‚à•x‚à• and

Let œà be a nondecreasing function defined on the positive integers such that œà‚Å¢(h)>0 for h‚â•1 (for example, œà‚Å¢(h)=log‚Å°(2‚Å¢h)). Following Kuipers and Niederreiter [85, p.¬†121, Definition 3.3], we say that an irrational number x is of type <œà if ‚à•h‚Å¢x‚à•‚â•1h‚Å¢œà‚Å¢(h) for all integers h‚â•1. If œà is a constant function, then we say that x is of constant type.

Lemma 6.

x‚ààŒ© is of constant type if and only if it has bounded partial quotients.

Proof.

Suppose that x‚ààŒ© is of constant type. So there is some K>0 such that ‚à•h‚Å¢x‚à•‚â•1h‚Å¢K for all integers h‚â•1. For n‚â•2 we have qn=an‚Å¢qn-1+qn-2, and hence, by (11),

an=qnqn-1-qn-2qn-1<qnqn-1‚â§qn‚ãÖK‚Å¢‚à•qn-1‚Å¢x‚à•<K,

showing that x has bounded partial quotients.

Suppose that x‚ààŒ© has bounded partial quotients, say an‚â§K for all n‚â•1. Let h be a positive integer and take qn‚â§h<qn+1. Then first by Theorem 2 and then by (12),

‚à•h‚Å¢x‚à•‚â•‚à•qn‚Å¢x‚à•>1qn+qn+1>12‚Å¢qn+1=12‚Å¢(an+1‚Å¢qn+qn-1)>12‚Å¢(an+1‚Å¢qn+qn),

and so

‚à•h‚Å¢x‚à•>12‚Å¢(K+1)‚Å¢1qn‚â•12‚Å¢(K+1)‚Å¢1h,

showing that x is of constant type. ‚àé

However, almost all x do not have bounded partial quotients [78, p.¬†60, Theorem 29]. Shallit [134] gives a survey on numbers with bounded partial quotients.

We state and prove a result of Khinchin‚Äôs [78, p.¬†69, Theorem 32] that we then use.

Lemma 7.

‚àëq=1‚àûf‚Å¢(q)<‚àû,

Because F has bounded variation, the set DF of x‚àà[0,1] at which F is differentiable is a Borel set with Œª‚Å¢(DF)=1. Theorem 10.

If x‚ààŒ© is of type <œà, then for all m‚â•1 we have

‚àëj=1m1‚à•j‚Å¢x‚à•<12‚Å¢m‚Å¢(œà‚Å¢(m)+log‚Å°m).
Proof.

1‚à•x‚à•‚â§œà‚Å¢(1)<12‚Å¢œà‚Å¢(1),

so the claim is true for m=1. Take m>1 and assume that the claim is true for all 1‚â§m‚Ä≤<m. We shall show that it is true for m.

Let qn‚â§m<qn+1. Either m<2‚Å¢qn or m‚â•2‚Å¢qn. In the first case, using Lemma 9 we have

‚àëj=1m1‚à•j‚Å¢x‚à• = ‚àëj=1qn1‚à•j‚Å¢x‚à•+‚àëj=1m-qn1‚à•(j+qn)‚Å¢x‚à•
< 12‚Å¢qn‚Å¢(œà‚Å¢(qn)+log‚Å°qn)
< 12‚Å¢m‚Å¢(œà‚Å¢(m)+log‚Å°m).

In the second case, using the induction assumption (with m‚Ä≤=m-qn) and Lemma 9 we have, because qn<m-qn,

‚àëj=1m1‚à•j‚Å¢x‚à• = ‚àëj=1m-qn1‚à•j‚Å¢x‚à•+‚àëj=1qn1‚à•(j+m-qn)‚Å¢x‚à•
< 12‚Å¢(m-qn)‚Å¢(œà‚Å¢(m-qn)+log‚Å°(m-qn))+6‚Å¢qn‚Å¢(œà‚Å¢(qn)+log‚Å°qn)
< 12‚Å¢(m-qn)‚Å¢(œà‚Å¢(m)+log‚Å°m)+12‚Å¢qn‚Å¢(œà‚Å¢(qn)+log‚Å°qn)
= 12‚Å¢m‚Å¢(œà‚Å¢(m)+log‚Å°m)-12‚Å¢qn‚Å¢(œà‚Å¢(m)-œà‚Å¢(qn)+log‚Å°m-log‚Å°qn)
‚â§ 12‚Å¢m‚Å¢(œà‚Å¢(m)+log‚Å°m).

The claim is true in both cases, which completes the proof by induction. ‚àé

Theorem 11.

‚àëj=1m1‚à•j‚Å¢x‚à•=O‚Å¢(m‚Å¢(log‚Å°m)1+œµ),

‚àé

For example, take x=-1+52, for which an‚Å¢(x)=1 for all n‚àà‚Ñï, and so in particular x has bounded partial quotients. In Figure 1 we plot 1m‚Å¢log‚Å°m‚ãÖ‚àëj=1m1‚à•j‚Å¢x‚à• for m=5000,‚Ä¶,40000. However, the estimate in Theorem 11 is not true for all x‚ààŒ©. Define a‚àà‚Ñï‚Ñï as follows. Let a1 be any element of ‚Ñï. Then inductively, define an+1 to be any element of ‚Ñï that is >qnn-1. Then for any n‚àà‚Ñï, using (11) and qn+1=an+1‚Å¢qn+qn-1>an+1‚Å¢qn we get

The following theorem gives a lower bound on the sum ‚àëj=1m1‚à•j‚Å¢x‚à•, cf. [150, p.¬†4, Theorem 3.1].

Theorem 13.

For almost all x‚ààŒ© there is some C>0 such that

For integers a,b with gcd‚Å°(a,b)=1, the Ford circle C‚Å¢(a,b) is the circle in ‚ÑÇ that touches the line Im‚Å¢z=0 at z=ab and has radius 12‚Å¢b2; in other words, C‚Å¢(a,b) is the circle in ‚ÑÇ with center ab+i2‚Å¢b2 and radius 12‚Å¢b2. 8 Discrepancy and exponential sums

Discrepancy and Diophantine approximation are covered by Kuipers and Niederreiter [85, Chapters 1‚Äì2 ] and by Drmota and Tichy [41, ¬ß¬ß1.1‚Äì1.4], especially [41, pp.¬†48‚Äì66, ¬ß1.4.1].

Let œâ=(xn), n‚â•1, be a sequence of real numbers, and let E‚äÇ[0,1). For a positive integer N, let A‚Å¢(E;N;œâ) be the number of xn, 1‚â§n‚â§N, such that R‚Å¢(xn)‚ààE. We say that the sequence œâ is uniformly distributed modulo 1 if we have for all a and b with 0‚â§a<b‚â§1 that

limN‚Üí‚àû‚Å°A‚Å¢([a,b);N;œâ)N=b-a.

It can be shown [85, p. 3, Corollary 1.1] that a sequence xn is uniformly distributed modulo 1 if and only if for every Riemann integrable function f:[0,1]‚Üí‚Ñù we have

limN‚Üí‚àû‚Å°1N‚Å¢‚àën=1Nf‚Å¢(R‚Å¢(xn))=‚à´01f‚Å¢(t)‚Å¢ùëët. (18)

Thus, if a sequence is uniformly distributed then the integral of any Riemann integrable function on [0,1] can be approximated by sampling according to this sequence. This approximation can be quantified using the notion of discrepancy.

It can be proved [85, p.¬†7, Theorem 2.1] that a sequence xn is uniformly distributed modulo 1 if and only if for all nonzero integers h we have

limN‚Üí‚àû‚Å°1N‚Å¢‚àën=1Ne2‚Å¢œÄ‚Å¢i‚Å¢h‚Å¢xn=0;

this is called Weyl‚Äôs criterion. But if x‚ààŒ©, then

|‚àën=1Ne2‚Å¢œÄ‚Å¢i‚Å¢h‚Å¢n‚Å¢x|=|1-e2‚Å¢œÄ‚Å¢i‚Å¢h‚Å¢N‚Å¢x1-e2‚Å¢œÄ‚Å¢i‚Å¢h‚Å¢x|‚â§2|1-e2‚Å¢œÄ‚Å¢i‚Å¢h‚Å¢x|=1|sin‚Å°œÄ‚Å¢h‚Å¢x|. (19)

We thus obtain the following theorem.

Theorem 19.

If x‚ààŒ© then the sequence n‚Å¢x is uniformly distributed modulo 1.

The discrepancy of a sequence œâ is defined, for N a positive integer, by

DN‚Å¢(œâ)=sup0‚â§a<b‚â§1‚Å°|A‚Å¢([a,b);N;œâ)N-(b-a)|

One proves that the sequence œâ is uniformly distributed modulo 1 if and only if DN‚Å¢(œâ)‚Üí0 as N‚Üí‚àû [85, p.¬†89, Theorem 1.1].

For f:[0,1]‚Üí‚Ñù, let V‚Å¢(f) denote the total variation of f. Koksma‚Äôs inequality [85, p.¬†143, Theorem 5.1] states that for any sequence œâ=(xn), for any f:[0,1]‚Üí‚Ñù of bounded variation, and for any positive integer N, we have

|1N‚Å¢‚àën=1Nf‚Å¢(R‚Å¢(xn))-‚à´01f‚Å¢(t)‚Å¢ùëët|‚â§V‚Å¢(f)‚Å¢DN‚Å¢(œâ). (20)

Following Kuipers and Niederreiter [85, p.¬†122, Lemma 3.2], we can bound the discrepancy of the sequence n‚Å¢x in terms of the sum on the left-hand side of Theorem 14

Lemma 20.

There is some C>0 such that for all x‚ààŒ©, œâ=(n‚Å¢x), and for all positive integers m we have

DN‚Å¢(œâ)<C‚Å¢(1m+1N‚Å¢‚àëj=1m1j‚Å¢‚à•j‚Å¢x‚à•).
Proof.

We shall use the following inequality, which lets us bound the discrepancy of a sequence in terms of exponential sums formed from the elements of the sequence. The Erd≈ës-Tur√°n theorem [85, p.¬†114, Eq. 2.42] states that there is some constant C>0 such that for any sequence œâ=(xn) of real numbers, any positive integer N, and any positive integer m we have

DN‚Å¢(œâ)‚â§C‚Å¢(1m+‚àëj=1m1j‚Å¢|1N‚Å¢‚àën=1Ne2‚Å¢œÄ‚Å¢i‚Å¢j‚Å¢xn|). (21)

Take xn=n‚Å¢x. For each j‚â•1, by (19) we have

|‚àën=1Ne2‚Å¢œÄ‚Å¢i‚Å¢j‚Å¢n‚Å¢x|‚â§1|sin‚Å°œÄ‚Å¢j‚Å¢x|=1sin‚Å°(œÄ‚Å¢‚à•j‚Å¢x‚à•).

But sin‚Å°t‚â•2œÄ‚Å¢t for 0‚â§t‚â§œÄ2, so

which is the claim. ‚àé

It follows from Theorem 14 and Lemma 20 (taking m=N) that if x is of type <K‚Å¢(log‚Å°h)1+œµ then

DN‚Å¢(œâ)=O‚Å¢((log‚Å°N)2+œµN). (22)

In fact, it can be proved that if x‚àà‚Ñ¨K then, for g=1+52 [85, p.¬†125, Theorem 3.4],

DN‚Å¢(œâ)‚â§3‚Å¢N-1+(1log‚Å°g+Klog‚Å°(K+1))‚Å¢N-1‚Å¢log‚Å°N.

We use the above bounds in the proof of the following theorem.

Theorem 21.

Let œµ>0. For almost all x we have

‚àën=1N‚à•n‚Å¢x‚à•=N4+O‚Å¢((log‚Å°N)2+œµ),

‚àën=1N‚à•n‚Å¢x‚à•=N4+O‚Å¢((log‚Å°N)2).

Let f‚Å¢(t)=‚à•t‚à•. Then V‚Å¢(f)=1 and ‚à´01f‚Å¢(t)‚Å¢ùëët=14, so we get from Koksma‚Äôs inequality (20) that

‚àën=1N‚à•n‚Å¢x‚à•=N4+O‚Å¢(N‚Å¢DN‚Å¢(œâ)).

The claims then follow respectively from (22) and (23). ‚àé

Like we mentioned at the beginning of ¬ß6, because |sin‚Å°(œÄ‚Å¢x)|=sin‚Å°(œÄ‚Å¢‚à•x‚à•)‚â§œÄ‚Å¢‚à•x‚à• and |sin‚Å°(œÄ‚Å¢x)|=sin‚Å°(œÄ‚Å¢‚à•x‚à•)‚â•2œÄ‚ãÖœÄ‚Å¢‚à•x‚à•=2‚Å¢‚à•x‚à•, we have

2‚Å¢‚àën=1N‚à•n‚Å¢x‚à•‚â§‚àën=1N|sin‚Å°(œÄ‚Å¢n‚Å¢x)|‚â§œÄ‚Å¢‚àën=1N‚à•n‚Å¢x‚à•.

We can investigate the sum ‚àën=1NR‚Å¢(n‚Å¢x) rather than ‚àën=1N‚à•n‚Å¢x‚à•; see Lang [92, p.¬†37, Theorem 1], who proves that for almost all x‚ààŒ©,

For x‚ààŒ©, let qn=qn‚Å¢(x), the denominator of the nth convergent of the continued fraction expansion of x, and let an=an‚Å¢(x), the nth partial quotient of the continued fraction expansion of x. For m‚â•1, one can prove [18, p.¬†211, Proposition¬†1] that m can be written in one and only one way in the form

where (i) 0‚â§z1‚â§a1-1, (ii) 0‚â§zk‚â§ak for k‚â•2, (iii) for k‚â•1, if zk+1=ak+1 then zk=0, and (iv) zt‚â†0 and zk=0 for k>t. The expression (24) is called the Ostrowski expansion of m. We emphasize that this expansion depends on x. Berth√© [18] surveys applications of this numeration system in combinatorics. For n‚â•0, define d2‚Å¢n=q2‚Å¢n‚Å¢x-p2‚Å¢n and d2‚Å¢n+1=p2‚Å¢n+1-q2‚Å¢n+1‚Å¢x. Brown and Shiue [24, p.¬†184, Theorem¬†1] prove that for x‚ààŒ©,

9 Dirichlet series

The result of de la Vall√©e-Poussin [34] stated in ¬ß3 implies that there is no s such that for all irrational x the Dirichlet series ‚àën=1‚àûn-s|sin‚Å°n‚Å¢œÄ‚Å¢x| converges. For a Dirichlet series ‚àën=1‚àûan‚Å¢n-s, one can show [143, pp.¬†289‚Äì290, ¬ß9.11] that if the series is convergent at s=œÉ0+i‚Å¢t0, then for œÉ>œÉ0 and any t the series is convergent at s=œÉ+i‚Å¢t. cannot be analytically continued to any domain that includes s=œÉ0 [67, p.¬†101, Proposition¬†18].

œÉ0=lim supn‚Üí‚àû‚Å°log‚Å°|sn|log‚Å°n.

For a power series ‚àëan‚Å¢zn with radius of convergence 0‚â§R‚â§‚àû, the Cauchy-Hadamard formula [124, p.¬†111, Chapter 4, ¬ß1] states

Lemma 23.

If x‚ààŒ©, then the power series

‚àën=1‚àûzn‚à•n‚Å¢x‚à•

Therefore, using limn‚Üí‚àû‚Å°21/n=1, we have

lim infn‚Üí‚àû‚Å°|sin‚Å°(œÄ‚Å¢n‚Å¢x)|1/n‚â•lim infn‚Üí‚àû‚Å°(2‚Å¢‚à•n‚Å¢x‚à•)1/n=lim infn‚Üí‚àû‚Å°‚à•n‚Å¢x‚à•1/n,

We show in the following theorem that for almost all x, the power series ‚àën=1‚àûzn‚à•n‚Å¢x‚à• has radius of convergence 1.

Theorem 24.

For almost all x‚ààŒ©, the power series

‚àën=1‚àûzn‚à•n‚Å¢x‚à• (27)

Proof.

For x‚ààŒ©, let Rx be the radius of convergence of the power series (27). We have 0<‚à•n‚Å¢x‚à•<12, so 1‚à•n‚Å¢x‚à•>2. Therefore ‚àën=1N1‚à•n‚Å¢x‚à•‚Üí‚àû as N‚Üí‚àû, and so the power series (27) diverges at z=1. Therefore Rx‚â§1 for all x‚ààŒ©.

We shall use Lemma 7 to get a lower bound on Rx that holds for almost all x‚ààŒ©. Let A={x‚ààŒ©:Rx<1}, let Am={x‚ààŒ©:Rx<1-1m}, and let Bm be those x‚ààŒ© such that ‚à•n‚Å¢x‚à•1/n<1-1m infinitely often. Œº‚Å¢(A)‚â§‚àëm=2‚àûŒº‚Å¢(Am)=0,

In fact, we can prove the above theorem using the bounds we obtained in Theorem 11. By Theorem 11, for almost all x‚ààŒ© we have that ‚àëj=1m1‚à•j‚Å¢x‚à•=O‚Å¢(m2). Let X be a measure space with probability measure Œª. Following [137, p.¬†21, Definition 3.6], we say that a measure preserving map T:X‚ÜíX is r-fold mixing if for all g,f1,‚Ä¶,fr‚ààLr+1‚Å¢(X) we have

limm1‚Üí‚àû,‚Ä¶,mr‚Üí‚àû‚Å°‚à´Xg‚Å¢(t)‚ãÖ‚àèk=1rfk‚Å¢(T‚àëj=1kmj‚Å¢(t))‚Å¢d‚Å¢Œª‚Å¢(t)=(‚à´Xg‚Å¢(t)‚Å¢ùëëŒª‚Å¢(t))‚Å¢‚àèk=1r(‚à´Xfk‚Å¢(t)‚Å¢ùëëŒª‚Å¢(t)). (33)

If for each r the map T is r-fold mixing, we say that T is mixing of all orders.

Let q‚â•2 be an integer, and define Tq:[0,1]‚Üí[0,1] by Tq‚Å¢(t)=R‚Å¢(q‚Å¢t). We assert that Tq is mixing of all orders. This can be proved by first showing that the dynamical system ([0,1],Œº,Tq) is isomorphic to a Bernoulli shift (cf. [44, p.¬†17, Example 2.8]). This implies that if the Bernoulli shift is r-fold mixing then Tq is r-fold mixing. One then shows that a Bernoulli shift is mixing of all orders [44, p.¬†53, Exercise 2.7.9]. Using that Tq is mixing of all orders gets us the following result.

12 Conclusions

Kac and Salem [73] prove the following. Let ck be a sequence of nonnegative real numbers for which ‚àëk=1‚àûck<‚àû. If the series

converges.

Let X be a random variable that is uniformly distributed on [0,1]. Kesten [77, p.¬†111, Theorem 1 ] proves that if ‚àëk=0‚àû|ck|<‚àû, then the series

in probability. Stated using measure theory, the conclusion is that for each œµ>0,

For ùïãd=‚Ñùd/‚Ñ§d=(‚Ñù/‚Ñ§)d, let œÉ be Haar measure on ùïã and let œÉd=‚®Ç1‚â§j‚â§dœÉ be Haar measure on ùïãd, with œÉ‚Å¢(ùïã)=1. A sequence t‚Å¢(n)‚ààùïãd, n‚â•1, is said to be uniformly distributed if for any arcs I1,‚Ä¶,Id in ùïã, with I=‚àèj=1dIj,

Kronecker‚Äôs approximation theorem [144, p.¬†108, Theorem 6.3] states that if Œ±1,‚Ä¶,Œ±d‚àà‚Ñù and {1,Œ±1,‚Ä¶,Œ±d} is linearly independent over ‚Ñö, then the sequence (n‚Å¢Œ±1+‚Ñ§,‚Ä¶,n‚Å¢Œ±d+‚Ñ§), n‚â•1, is uniformly distributed in ùïãd. Meyer [100] is a thorough presentation of multidimensional Diophantine approximation and Diophantine approximation with locally compact abelian groups, and harmonic analysis involving sets satisfying various Diophantine properties.

See Abraham and Marsden [1, p. 395, Proposition 5.2.23] and [1, pp. 818-820, Proposition 5.2.23].

Measure theoretic results in Diophantine approximation are presented in Khinchin [78], Einsiedler and Ward [44, Chapter 3], Rockett and Sz√ºsz [127, Chapters V and VI], Billingsley [19, pp.¬†13‚Äì15, 319‚Äì326], Kac [74, Chapter 5], Bugeaud [25], and Kesseb√∂hmer, Munday and Stratmann [76]. The significance of continued fraction expansions of irrational numbers in the early history of axiomatic probability theory is described by Barone and Novikoff [8], Durand and Mazliak [43], and von Plato [151]. Veech [147] presents material on Diophantine approximation in the setting of topological dynamics.

We have been interested in results about almost all x‚ààŒ©, using Lebesgue measure Œº on [0,1]. If E‚äÇŒ© has Œº‚Å¢(E)=0, one can ask what the Hausdorff dimension dimH‚Å°E of the set E is. Let ‚Ñ¨K be the set of those x‚ààŒ© such that an‚Å¢(x)‚â§K for all n‚â•1, and let ‚Ñ¨=‚ãÉK‚â•1‚Ñ¨K, the set of those x‚ààŒ© with bounded partial quotients. Dodson and Kristensen [39] give a survey of results on the Hausdorff dimension of various sets that appear in Diophantine approximation.

For a decreasing positive function œà, the set

W‚Å¢(œà)={x‚àà[0,1]:‚à•q‚Å¢x‚à•<q‚Å¢œà‚Å¢(q)¬†for infinitely many¬†q‚àà‚Ñï}

W‚Å¢(œà)=lim supn‚Üí‚àû‚Å°W‚Å¢(œà,n)=‚ãÇN=1‚àû‚ãÉn=N‚àûW‚Å¢(œà,n),

where

One can exploit nice properties of limsup sets, such as the Borel-Cantelli lemma and invariance under ergodic transformations, to prove fundamental results in Diophantine approximation. Beresnevich, Dickinson and Velani [16] use this motiviation of Diophantine approximation to build a framework for a natural class of limsup sets on compact metric spaces. Their general results readily imply the divergent case of Khinchin‚Äôs theorem: Œº‚Å¢(W‚Å¢(œà))=0 if ‚àëq‚Å¢œà‚Å¢(q)<‚àû (Lemma 7) and Œº‚Å¢(W‚Å¢(œà))=1 if ‚àëq‚Å¢œà‚Å¢(q)=‚àû. Their framework also establishes the divergent case of Jarn√≠k‚Äôs theorem: the f-Hausdorff dimension of W‚Å¢(œà) is 0 if ‚àëq‚Å¢f‚Å¢(œà‚Å¢(q))<‚àû and is infinity if ‚àëq‚Å¢f‚Å¢(œà‚Å¢(q))=‚àû, where f is a dimension function such that r-1‚Å¢f‚Å¢(r)‚Üí‚àû as r‚Üí0, and r-1‚Å¢f‚Å¢(r) is decreasing.

As well, rather than making statements about subsets of Œ© of measure 1, we can talk about sets whose complements are meager. (Measure theoretically, the notion of a negligible set is made precise as a set of measure 0, and topologically the notion of a negligible set is made precise as a meager set.) Some results of this type are proved in Oxtoby [111, Chapter 2].

Let p be prime, let Np={0,‚Ä¶,p-1}, and let ‚Ñöp‚äÇ‚àè‚Ñ§Np be the p-adic numbers. For x‚àà‚Ñöp let

It would be a useful project to give an organized presentation of Hardy and Littlewood‚Äôs results on Diophantine approximation. Their papers in this area are all included in Hardy‚Äôs collected works [61]. Hardy and Littlewood proved many pleasant results on various sums and series with coefficients related to sin‚Å°(n‚Å¢œÄ‚Å¢x) and R‚Å¢(n‚Å¢x). It would be desirable to streamline and systematically prove these results, to let a modern reader to be able to understand them without having to read the whole series of papers to figure out what results are being tacitly used from earlier work or assumed as general knowledge. There is only a bare summary of Hardy and Littlewood‚Äôs work in the commentary in Hardy‚Äôs collected papers. Hardy‚Äôs work on Diophantine approximation is briefly summarized by Mordell [104]. See also lecture V of Hardy‚Äôs lectures on Ramanujan [60].
